content: The Act titled "Automobile Fuel Efficiency Improvements Act of 2003" includes phased increases in fuel economy standards. The "Automobile Fuel Efficiency Improvements Act of 2003" mandates phased increases in fuel economy standards for passenger automobiles, with minimum standards set for different model years. The "Automobile Fuel Efficiency Improvements Act of 2003" mandates phased increases in fuel economy standards for passenger automobiles, with minimum standards set for different model years. Automobiles manufactured by a manufacturer in a model year shall meet specific miles per gallon requirements, increasing from 25 to 40 miles per gallon based on the model year range. The fuel economy standards for passenger automobiles are mandated to increase gradually, with minimum requirements set for different model years. The standards range from 25 to 40 miles per gallon, with specific targets for each model year. Amendments to the regulations aim to raise the applicable standards rather than simply amending them. Amendments to increase fuel economy standards for non-passenger automobiles by removing certain language and designating new paragraphs. Amendments to increase fuel economy standards for non-passenger automobiles by removing language and realigning paragraphs. The fuel economy standards for non-passenger automobiles have been amended to set specific mileage requirements for different model years, starting from 17 miles per gallon for model years after 1984 and before 2006, increasing to 24.5 miles per gallon for model years after 2011 and before 2015. The fuel economy standards for non-passenger automobiles have been amended to set specific mileage requirements for different model years, ranging from 17 to 27.5 miles per gallon. Additionally, there is a provision for the Secretary to increase the average fuel economy at least 18 months before each model year after 2015. The fuel economy standard after model year 2014 is set at 27.5 miles per gallon, with a provision for the Secretary to increase it at least 18 months before each model year after 2015. If the standard is not increased within 24 months, a report must be submitted to Congress explaining the reasons for not increasing it. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress within 90 days after 24 months if the fuel economy standard is not increased as required. SEC. 3. INCREASED INCLUSIVENESS OF DEFINITIONS OF AUTOMOBILE AND PASSENGER AUTOMOBILE. The definition of "Automobile" in section 32901(a) of title 49, United States Code, is amended to increase the weight limit to 12,000 pounds and the fuel economy standard to 14,000 pounds. In section 32901(a) of title 49, United States Code, the weight limit for automobiles is increased to 14,000 pounds and the fuel economy standard is also set at 14,000 pounds. Additionally, section 32908(a)(1) is amended to reflect the new weight limit of 14,000 pounds. The weight limit for passenger automobiles in section 32901(a) of title 49, United States Code, is increased to 14,000 pounds. The definition of a passenger automobile is also amended to exclude vehicles over 12,000 pounds designed for transporting persons. The definition of a passenger automobile is amended to exclude vehicles over 12,000 pounds designed for transporting persons, with exceptions for vehicles with load carrying devices, seating capacity over 12 persons, or over 9 persons behind the driver's seat. The definition of a passenger automobile is amended to exclude vehicles over 12,000 pounds designed for transporting persons, with exceptions for vehicles with load carrying devices, seating capacity over 12 persons, or over 9 persons behind the driver's seat. Vehicles with cargo areas of at least 6 feet in length that do not extend beyond the frame and are open or designed for use as open areas but enclosed are also included. The definition of a passenger automobile is amended to exclude vehicles over 12,000 pounds designed for transporting persons, with exceptions for vehicles with load carrying devices, seating capacity over 12 persons, or over 9 persons behind the driver's seat. The amendments made by this section apply to automobiles manufactured for model years after the enactment of this Act. The text chunk "SEC. 4. CIVIL PENALTIES." is a concise statement regarding civil penalties. Increased penalty for violations of fuel economy standards under section 32912 of title 49, United States Code, amended to raise the dollar amount to $10 annually. The penalty for violations of fuel economy standards under section 32912 of title 49, United States Code, is increased to $10 annually and will be adjusted each year based on the price index. The penalty for violations of fuel economy standards is increased annually by adjusting the dollar amount based on the Consumer Price Index for all-urban consumers published by the Department of Labor. The penalty for violations of fuel economy standards is adjusted annually based on the Consumer Price Index for all-urban consumers. The amendments in this section round penalties to the nearest $0.10 and apply to automobiles manufactured for model years after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. ACCURATE FUEL ECONOMY TESTING. Biennial Report on Testing Quality: The Secretary of Transportation must submit a report to Congress every odd-numbered year on the quality of automobile fuel economy testing for all available technologies. The Secretary of Transportation must submit a biennial report to Congress on the quality of automobile fuel economy testing for all available technologies, including an assessment of accuracy and planned changes in testing methodology. The biennial report to Congress must assess the accuracy of automobile fuel economy testing and discuss planned changes in testing methodology. The Secretary of Transportation and the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency must consult on planned changes to automobile fuel economy testing methodology. The first report under section 32920 of title 49, United States Code, shall be submitted to Congress in 2005. The Secretary of Transportation will conduct a study to determine the most accurate automobile fuel economy testing process. The John A. Volpe National Transportation Systems Center will conduct a study to determine the most accurate automobile fuel economy testing process for highway, urban, and combined use. The John A. Volpe National Transportation Systems Center will conduct a study to determine the most accurate automobile fuel economy testing process for highway, urban, and combined use, comparing it with the current testing process under chapter 329 of title 49, United States Code. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress two years after the enactment of the Act on the study conducted by the John A. Volpe National Transportation Systems Center to determine the most accurate automobile fuel economy testing process for highway, urban, and combined use. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress two years after the enactment of the Act, detailing the results of a study on accurate automobile fuel economy testing processes. The report will include determinations, comparisons, and an estimate of the average adjustment to fuel economy ratings. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress two years after the enactment of the Act, detailing determinations, comparisons, and an estimate of the average adjustment to automobile fuel economy ratings to conform closely to testing processes. The Act requires automobile fuel economy ratings to be revised to closely conform to the most accurate testing process within 180 days of the report to Congress. The Secretary of Transportation must revise the testing procedure for accurately measuring automobile fuel economy ratings within 180 days of the report to Congress. The Secretary of Transportation must prescribe a revised testing procedure for measuring actual automobile fuel economy and apply it to determine the average fuel economy of cars manufactured after 2006. The Secretary of Transportation must prescribe a revised testing procedure based on accurate measures of actual automobile fuel economy for cars manufactured after 2006. The Secretary of Transportation will amend average fuel economy standards for cars manufactured after model year 2006 based on accurate testing procedures. The Secretary of Transportation will adjust average fuel economy standards for cars manufactured after 2006 to reflect improved accuracy in calculating fuel economy. The Secretary of Transportation will adjust average fuel economy standards for cars manufactured after 2006 to ensure they are at least as stringent as the previous standards under section 32902 of title 49, United States Code. The Secretary will adjust fuel economy standards for post-2006 cars to be as strict as previous standards under section 32902 of title 49, US Code. SEC. 6. STANDARDS FOR EXECUTIVE AGENCY AUTOMOBILES. Section 32917 of title 49, United States Code, is amended to set fleet average fuel economy standards for non-passenger automobiles. The fleet average fuel economy standards for non-passenger automobiles are set under section 32917 of title 49, United States Code. The standards require a minimum fuel economy for non-passenger automobiles based on the model year. The fleet average fuel economy standards for non-passenger automobiles are set under section 32917 of title 49, United States Code, requiring a minimum fuel economy based on the model year. In the case of passenger automobiles, a fleet average fuel economy for the year must meet the applicable standard for that model year. For non-passenger or passenger automobiles, the fleet average fuel economy standards are determined based on the model year. The calculation includes both non-passenger and passenger automobiles separately. The President shall prescribe regulations that require a minimum number of exceptionally fuel-efficient vehicles. The President must ensure that at least 20% of executive agencies' leased or purchased passenger automobiles in a fiscal year have a fuel economy rating 5 miles per gallon higher than the average standard. In a fiscal year, executive agencies must ensure that 20% of leased or purchased passenger automobiles have a fuel economy rating at least 5 miles per gallon higher than the average standard. Additionally, starting in fiscal year 2009, at least 10,000 vehicles in the executive agencies' fleet must meet this fuel economy requirement. Starting in fiscal year 2009, executive agencies must ensure that at least 10,000 vehicles in their fleet have a fuel economy at least 5 miles per gallon higher than the average standard for that model year.
